{{use American English|date=November 2013}} {{use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} '''Lemrick Nelson, Jr.''' (born July 31, 1975)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-2nd-circuit/1287462.html |title=''United States v. Nelson'' |date=October 17, 1995 |publisher=United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit |accessdate=July 28, 2010 }}</ref> is an African-American man<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5y8zhmn-q4QC&pg=PA496&dq=%22lemrick+nelson%22+trinidadian#v=onepage&q=%22lemrick%20nelson%22%20trinidadian&f=false |title=Strangers in the land: Blacks, Jews, post-Holocaust America|author=Eric J. Sundquist|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2005|page=496|isbn=9780674019423|accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref> who stabbed [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] student [[Yankel Rosenbaum]] to death during the racial unrest of the 1991 [[Crown Heights riot]].<ref name="nydailynews2">{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/09/12/2010-09-12_lemrick_nelson_stabbed_in_the_head_with_ice_pick_19_years_after_knifing_student_.html |title=Lemrick Nelson stabbed in the head with ice pick, 19 years after knifing student to death in riots |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=August 19, 1991 |accessdate=September 14, 2010 | location=New York | first1=Barry | last1=Paddock | first2=John | last2=Lauinger | first3=Helen | last3=Kennedy}}</ref><ref name="nytimes5">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/13/nyregion/13lemrick.html | work=The New York Times | title=Man Convicted in 1991 Racial Unrest Is Stabbed | date=September 12, 2010}}</ref> Though his lawyer did not deny at his trial that Nelson stabbed Rosenbaum, he argued that the killing had nothing to do with Rosenbaum's being Jewish.<ref name="googlecivil">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=HjjV4DpDNh0C&pg=PA22&dq=civil-rights+%22lemrick+nelson%22#v=onepage&q=civil-rights%20%22lemrick%20nelson%22&f=false |title=Hate crimes: a reference handbook |author=Donald Altschiller|publisher=ABC-CLIO |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2010|isbn=9781851096244 |year=2005 }}</ref>
Nelson was arrested several times on unrelated charges over the following years. In a third trial for Rosenbaum's murder, Nelson was convicted of violating Rosenbaum's [[civil rights]] in the murder, and served a 10-year sentence. Nelson admitted for the first time at his 2003 trial that he had stabbed Rosenbaum.
==Early life== Nelson is the son of immigrants to the United States from [[Trinidad]], Lemrick Nelson Sr. (formerly a baker) and his former wife, Valerie Evans.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e_ohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YqMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1128,5345685&dq=lemrick-nelson&hl=en "Jews, Blacks, heal riot-torn area"], ''Reading Eagle'', August 11, 2001. Retrieved July 28, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mitchell |first=Alison |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/30/nyregion/bitterness-for-one-family-and-relief-for-the-other.html |title=Bitterness for One Family and Relief for the Other |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=October 30, 1992 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gothamgazette.com/citizen/jan02/13.shtml |title=The Citizen |work=Gotham Gazette |date=January 9, 2002 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=N1NUZPsrda0C&pg=PA67&dq=%22lemrick+nelson%22+trinidadian#v=onepage&q=%22lemrick%20nelson%22%20trinidadian&f=false |title=Why Blacks Fear 'America's Mayor': Reporting Police Brutality and Black Activist Politics Under Rudy Giuliani |author=Peter Noel|publisher=iUniverse|year= 2007| isbn=0-595-47657-0 |page= 67|accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref> According to information presented by his lawyers in 1995, Nelson had a troubled childhood. His mother, who reportedly suffered from mental illness, repeatedly tried to [[Abortion|abort]] him before he was born. As an infant, he lived with his mother at a shelter for battered women. Nelson's earliest memories involved a physical altercation between his father and mother. Eventually, his mother abandoned him when he was 18 months old.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/nyregion/prosecutors-still-seek-to-try-91-crown-hts-suspect-as-adult.html |title=Prosecutors Still Seek to Try '91 Crown Hts. Suspect as Adult |last=McKinley |first=James C. |date=August 30, 1995 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=July 28, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1995/07/20/1995-07-20_lemrick_called_troubled_kid.html |title=Lemrick Called Troubled Kid |last=Smith |first=Greg B. |date=July 20, 1995 |work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] |accessdate=July 28, 2010 }}</ref> Nelson was identified as a "youngster at risk" in elementary school.<ref name="findacase1">{{cite web|url=http://ny.findacase.com/research/wfrmDocViewer.aspx/xq/fac.%5CFDCT%5CENY%5C1996%5C19960321_0000055.ENY.htm/qx |title= U.S. v. Nelson |publisher=U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of NY |date=March 21, 1996 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref> He had poor motivation, disrupted classes, and did poorly academically.<ref name="findacase1"/>
Nelson was interviewed and tested in November 1994 by psychologists Dr. Naftali Berrill, and Dr. Ife Landsmark.<ref name="findacase1"/> Both rated his I.Q. as low average to average, while Landsmark noted a high-average score in a language-free test.<ref name="findacase1"/> The doctors characterized his symptoms as those of a [[conduct disorder]] without any significant [[psychopathology]].<ref name="findacase1"/>
==Killing of Yankel Rosenbaum==
===Events of August 19–20, 1991=== After seven-year-old African-American Gavin Cato was accidentally struck and killed by an automobile in the motorcade of a prominent [[Hasidic]] rabbi on August 19, 1991,<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-3686875.html "Lemrick Nelson, Again"], by Lawrence A. Hoffman, ''The Jewish Week'', August 25, 1994. Retrieved July 27, 2010.</ref> some Black residents of [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]] rioted. Shortly after the riot began, a group of 12–20 young Black men shouting "Kill the Jew", surrounded Yankel Rosenbaum, a 29-year-old [[Australia]]n [[University of Melbourne]] graduate student who was in the United States conducting doctoral research.<ref name="google1">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DF-ZMgBPEVMC&pg=PA50&dq=%22lemrick+nelson%22#v=onepage&q=%22lemrick%20nelson%22&f=false |title=The American Criminal Justice System ... – Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2010|isbn=9780313383472 |year=2010 }}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=StQXz-ClGuUC&pg=PA197&dq=%22lemrick+nelson%22#v=onepage&q=%22lemrick%20nelson%22&f=false |title=Crown Heights: Blacks, Jews, and the 1991 Brooklyn Riot |author=Edward S. Shapiro|publisher=UPNE |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2010|isbn=9781584655619 |year=2006 }}</ref> Nelson stabbed Rosenbaum in the back and was apprehended by police a short time later.<ref name="google2"/><ref name="google3">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y_iZX71ejZgC&pg=PA46&dq=%22killer%22+%22lemrick+nelson%22#v=onepage&q=%22killer%22%20%22lemrick%20nelson%22&f=false |title=Race and Religion Among the Chosen Peoples of Crown Heights |author=Henry Goldschmidt|publisher=Rutgers University Press |date=2006 |accessdate=August 9, 2010|isbn=9780813538976 }}</ref><ref name="Books.google.com">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=RnR2AAAAMAAJ&q=civil-rights+%22lemrick+nelson%22&dq=civil-rights+%22lemrick+nelson%22 |title=What Would Martin Say? |publisher=HarperCollins |author=Clarence B. Jones, Joel Engel|date=2008 |accessdate=August 9, 2010|isbn=9780061253201 }}</ref> Before being taken to the hospital, Rosenbaum identified Nelson as the person who had stabbed him.<ref name="Wilson">{{cite web |url=http://www.njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/060806/ltCrownHeightsRiot.html |title=Crown Heights riot—fact, fiction, and plenty of blame |accessdate=October 20, 2007 |last=Wilson |first=Judy |coauthors= |year=2006 |DUPLICATE_work= |work=[[New Jersey Jewish News]]}}</ref>
Rosenbaum died from internal bleeding at Kings County Hospital. His medical treatment at the hospital was the subject of later litigation: doctors failed to notice one of Rosenbaum's four stab wounds for almost an hour.<ref>{{cite news|last=Newman |first=Andy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/17/nyregion/juror-explains-mixed-verdict-on-crown-hts.html|title=Juror Explains Mixed Verdict On Crown Hts |location=|newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 17, 2003 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref>
===Murder trial (1992)=== Nelson was tried on charges of murder as a hate crime in a New York state court in 1992. Nelson pleaded not guilty to the charge and denied stabbing Rosenbaum.<ref name="nytimes2003">{{cite news|last=Newman |first=Andy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/15/nyregion/the-crown-heights-verdict-overview-mixed-verdict-on-crown-hts-defense-happy.html?ref=lemrick_jr_nelson |title=The Crown Heights Verdict – Overview – Mixed Verdict On Crown Hts. – Defense Happy |location=|newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 15, 2003 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}}</ref>
Police testified that Nelson had confessed to murdering Rosenbaum to police officers.<ref name="nytimesOct1992">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/31/opinion/the-crown-heights-acquittal.html?ref=lemrick_jr_nelson |title=The Crown Heights Acquittal |location=New York City; Crown Heights (Nyc) |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 31, 1992 |accessdate=October 3, 2011}}</ref> Prosecutors claimed Nelson had been carrying a blood-stained knife inscribed with the word "KilleR" at the time he was arrested, but Nelson's defense denied the knife was his and suggested police officers had found it elsewhere. No evidence of fingerprints on the knife was presented.<ref name="nytimesOct1992"/> Despite media reports that the pants Nelson had been wearing at the time of his arrest had been bloody,<ref name="google2"/><ref name="google3"/><ref name="Books.google.com"/> prosecutors did not present evidence of bloodstains upon Nelson's clothing.<ref name="nytimesOct1992"/>
Nelson was acquitted of murder on October 29, 1992.<ref name="nytimesOct1992"/> The racial composition of the jury (which was considered relevant in the context of the racially charged atmosphere) is unclear: some contemporary reports described the jury as having consisted of six black jurors, four Hispanic jurors and two white jurors.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/news/features/47165/ |title='The New Anti-Semitism' |date=January 11, 1993 |work=New York Magazine |accessdate=October 2, 2011 }}</ref> Later reports described the jury as having consisted of eight black jurors, two white jurors and two Guyanese Americans of undisclosed race<ref name="nytimes2003"/> or as being "predominantly black".<ref name="DF-ZMgBPEVMC 2010, p. 50">[https://books.google.com/books?id=DF-ZMgBPEVMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+American+Criminal+Justice+System:+How+It+Works,+How+It+Doesn't,+and+How+to+Fix+It&hl=en&ei=MDBPTMK9A4P78AaGx53ZDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Gerhard Falk, ''The American Criminal Justice System: How It Works, How It Doesn't, and How to Fix It''], ABC-CLIO, 2010, p. 50. Retrieved July 27, 2010.</ref> It was claimed that after conclusion of the trial, some jurors attended a party hosted by Nelson's lawyer which honored Nelson as a "hero."<ref name="DF-ZMgBPEVMC 2010, p. 50"/>
===Violation of civil rights trials (1997 and 2003)===
In 1997, Nelson was convicted in federal court of violating Rosenbaum's civil rights. However, that verdict was vacated on appeal due to unfairness in the jury selection process.<ref name="nytimes2003"/>
A retrial was held in 2003. There were two primary issues of contention: whether Nelson's actions had been motivated by prejudice and whether Nelson's actions caused Rosenbaum's death.
In a departure from his position in the 1992 trial, Nelson admitted to having stabbed Rosenbaum and apologized to Rosenbaum's family for his actions.<ref name="Gourevitch">{{cite journal|first=Philip |last=Gourevitch |journal=The Jewish Forward |date=January 1993 |url=http://www.ex-iwp.org/docs/1993/Crown+Heights+Riot+Aftermath.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205030339/http://ex-iwp.org/docs/1993/Crown%2BHeights%2BRiot%2BAftermath.htm/ |archivedate=December 5, 2013 |title=The Crown Heights Riot & Its Aftermath |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9805EFDB1F30F932A1575BC0A9659C8B63|title=Penalty in Crown Hts. Case Means a Little More Jail Time|last=Newman|first=Andy|work=The New York Times|date=August 21, 2003|accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-L0DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=%22lemrick+nelson%22+%22civil+rights%22#v=onepage&q=%22lemrick%20nelson%22%20%22civil%20rights%22&f=false |title=End of New York Crown Heights Riot Court Case Bittersweet for Parents who Lost Children |publisher=''[[Jet (magazine)|JET]]'' |page=15|date=September 8, 2003 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Twist 2003">"In Twist, Defendant Admits to Stabbing In Crown Hts. in '91," ''The New York Times,'' April 29, 2003.</ref> However, he denied his actions had been motivated by prejudice, claiming he had joined the mob because he was intoxicated and "caught up in the excitement".<ref name="googlecivil"/><ref name="nytimes2003"/> Prosecutors claimed that Nelson had admitted he had attacked Rosenbaum only after hearing someone shout "Let's get the Jew!".<ref name="nytimes2003"/> Rosenbaum's family claimed videotapes showed that Nelson was not intoxicated and claimed the mob of which Nelson was a member had shouted: "There's a Jew, let's get the Jew."<ref name="Twist 2003"/>
On the issue of whether Nelson caused Rosenbaum's death, medical evidence was presented indicating that Rosenbaum had been stabbed four times, of which two of the wounds were fatal.<ref name="pqasb.pqarchiver.com">[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/nypost/access/337008331.html?dids=337008331:337008331&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+15%2C+2003&author=KATI+CORNELL+SMITH&pub=New+York+Post&desc=LEMRICK+GUILTY+-+BUT+HE+FACES+ONLY+2+YEARS+IN+JAIL&pqatl=google "Lemrick Guilty – but he faces only 2 years in jail"], by Kati Cornell Smith, ''[[New York Post]]'', May 15, 2003. Retrieved July 27, 2010.</ref>
On May 14, 2003, the jury found Nelson guilty of violating Rosenbaum's civil rights, but he was not found to have caused Rosenbaum's death.<ref name="pqasb.pqarchiver.com"/> According to [[Cornell University Law School|Cornell]] law professor Sherry Colb, the jury's verdict was "logically incoherent." Rosenbaum's family had filed a malpractice suit against the hospital where he died. The jury was supposed to—but did not—ignore this information in determining Nelson's guilt, reasoning that the hospital and Nelson could not both be guilty. Colb writes that "this line of reasoning can most generously be described as misguided and less generously as stupid."<ref>Sherry F. Colb, [http://writ.news.findlaw.com/colb/20030604.html ''The Verdict in the Lemrick Nelson Trial: Jury Deliberations Expose a Troubling Reality''], June 4, 2003, in FindLaw.</ref>
Nelson was subsequently sentenced to the maximum sentence of ten years' imprisonment.<ref name="google2"/> He served the full sentence (including time served before his 2003 trial) and was released on June 2, 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2004/06/03/2004-06-03_lemrick_nelson_s_out_of_jail.html|author=John Marzulli and Dave Godiner|title=Lemrick Nelson's Out of Jail |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |date=June 3, 2004 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}}</ref>
In a May 2010 interview with the ''[[New York Post]]'', Nelson indicated that he had stopped drinking; he said he considered stabbing Rosenbaum a "mistake" he made as "a kid".<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldstein |first=Joseph |url=http://www.nypost.com/f/news/local/brooklyn/crown_hts_thug_new_life_RRn9y1S44iYOFPMgRUt3zI |title=Crown Heights riot figure Lemrick Nelson lives quietly in Hillside, New Jersey |newspaper=New York Post |date=May 16, 2010 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}}</ref>
===Political and social reaction=== According to ''[[New York Magazine]]'', Nelson's initial acquittal fueled anger at Mayor [[David Dinkins]], with Dinkins becoming "a surrogate for Lemrick Nelson", in part because of Dinkins's support for the verdict, saying "I have no doubt that in this case the criminal-justice system has operated fairly and openly."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=o-QCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=The+Politics+of+grievance:+Dinkins,+the+Blacks,+and+the+Jews,&source=bl&ots=jU7UsUaRHT&sig=v27SvnpDJadVdmmA6yep6ZfL8c0&hl=en&ei=RQivTNf_H4H48Ab38pWfCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=surrogate&f=false "The Politics of grievance: Dinkins, the Blacks, and the Jews"], ''New York Magazine'', December 7, 1992, p. 19.</ref> According to Edward Shapiro, professor of history at [[Seton Hall University]], "it is possible that David Dinkins would have been re-elected mayor in 1993 had the jury not exonerated Lemrick Nelson on October 29, 1992." Shapiro has called the riot "the most serious anti-Semitic incident in American history".<ref name=Shapiro>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=StQXz-ClGuUC |accessdate=October 20, 2007 |last=Shapiro |first=Edward S. |year=2006 |title=Crown heights: Blacks, Jews, and the 1991 Brooklyn riot |location=[[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]], [[Massachusetts]] |publisher=[[Brandeis University]] Press, [[University Press of New England]]|page=xi|isbn=1-58465-561-5 }}</ref>
==Other incidents==
After being acquitted of Rosenbaum's murder in 1992, Nelson moved to a suburb of [[Atlanta, Georgia]], to live with a half-sister.<ref name="nytimes1995">{{cite news|last=Fried |first=Joseph P. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/07/nyregion/guilty-plea-by-suspect-in-slashing.html |title=Guilty Plea By Suspect In Slashing |location=Dekalb County (Ga); Crown Heights (Nyc) |newspaper=New York Times |date=February 7, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fried |first=Joseph P. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/28/nyregion/friend-of-crown-heights-suspect-says-he-confessed.html |title=Friend of Crown Heights Suspect Says He Confessed |location= |newspaper=New York Times|date=January 28, 1997 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref name="findlaw1">{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-2nd-circuit/1287462.html |title=U.S. v. Nelson |publisher=US 2nd Circuit |date= |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
===Aggravated assault and weapon charges (1994)=== Nelson was charged in January 1994 with [[aggravated assault]] for slashing Erik Heard, a high school classmate, because Heard had reported to school officials that Nelson had stolen money from another classmate. When he was arrested on March 5, 1994, Nelson was also charged with carrying a [[concealed weapon]] (a scalpel).<ref name="findacase1"/><ref name="nytimes1995"/><ref name="findlaw1"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Smothers |first=Ronald |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/23/nyregion/crown-hts-case-follows-youth-to-atlanta.html |title=Crown Hts. Case Follows Youth to Atlanta |location=Atlanta (Ga); Crown Heights (Nyc) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=April 23, 1994 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/02/nyregion/indictment-of-crown-hts-figure-is-sought.html |title=Indictment of Crown Hts. Figure Is Sought |location=Decatur (Ga); Crown Heights (Nyc) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=May 2, 1994 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
He pleaded guilty and was convicted on both charges in [[DeKalb County, Georgia|DeKalb County]] Superior Court in [[Decatur, Georgia]], in March 1995.<ref name="nytimes1995"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Jones |first=Charisse |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/nyregion/contrasting-reactions-as-they-hear-the-verdicts.html |title=The Crown Heights Verdict – The Defendants – Contrasting Reactions as They Hear the Verdicts |location=New York City; Crown Heights (NYC) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=February 11, 1997 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mckinley |first=James C. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/nyregion/prosecutors-still-seek-to-try-91-crown-hts-suspect-as-adult.html |title=Prosecutors Still Seek to Try '91 Crown Hts. Suspect as Adult |location=Crown Heights (Nyc) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=August 30, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fried |first=Joseph P. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/17/nyregion/a-new-crown-hts-trial-revisits-brooklyn-night-of-murder-in-91.html |title=A New Crown Hts. Trial Revisits Brooklyn Night of Murder in '91 |location= |newspaper=New York Times |date=January 17, 1997 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MEAgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0HwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6824,3385743&dq=lemrick-nelson+georgia&hl=en John Leo, "Racial Nullification Strikes Courts"], ''Sarasota Herald Tribune'', October 14, 1995. Retrieved July 28, 2010.</ref> He was sentenced to 90–120 days (of which he served 120 days) and three years' probation, and was banished from the State of Georgia.<ref name="nytimes1995"/><ref name="findlaw1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1997/02/11/1997-02-11_civil_rights_trial__the_play.html |title=Civil Rights Trial: The Players |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=February 11, 1997 |accessdate=July 29, 2010 | location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kennedy |first=Randy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/15/nyregion/man-held-in-role-in-crown-hts-case.html |title=Man Held In Role In Crown Hts. Case |location=Crown Heights (Nyc) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=August 15, 1996 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] also noted that Nelson was expelled from school as a result of the incident, and physically resisted arrest.<ref name="findlaw1"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Fried |first=Joseph P. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/10/nyregion/crown-heights-prosecuters-portray-accused-man-19-poor-candidate-for.html |title=Crown Heights Prosecuters Portray Accused Man, 19, as Poor Candidate for Rehabilitation |location= |newspaper=New York Times|date=September 10, 1994 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
===Disorderly conduct, resisting arrest, and harassment charges (1995)=== After spending approximately two years in Georgia, Nelson returned to the New York area in 1994.<ref name="nytimes4"/> He lived with his mother in New Jersey, and his father in Crown Heights.<ref name="nytimes4">{{cite news|last=Pierre |first=Garry |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/24/nyregion/youth-charged-in-crown-heights-incident-is-arrested-again.html |title=Youth Charged In Crown Heights Incident Is Arrested Again |location= |newspaper=New York Times|date=June 24, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
In the early hours of June 23, 1995, Nelson and five other men were gathered outside an apartment building on Schenectady Avenue in Crown Heights.<ref name="nydailynews1995">{{cite news|last=Raftery |first=Tom |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1995/06/24/1995-06-24_lemrick_nabbed__crown_hts__s.html |title=Lemrick Nabbed Crown Hts. Scuffle Crown Hts. Scuffle Lemrick Nabbed |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=June 24, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010 | location=New York}}</ref> Police approached the men after receiving a complaint call and one man was summonsed for possession of marijuana. Nelson was subsequently arrested and charged with second-degree assault, [[resisting arrest]] and disorderly conduct.<ref name="nytimes4"/>
On arraignment, police claimed that Nelson had pushed and punched an officer who had asked him for identification and attempted to search him, causing the officer to fall and sprain his wrist.<ref name="nytimes4"/><ref name="nydailynews1995"/> Nelson's attorney claimed that the police officers had harassed and assaulted Nelson by beating him on the head with a flashlight.<ref name="nytimes4"/><ref name="nydailynews1995"/><ref name="nytimes3">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/05/nyregion/acquitted-of-murder-but-arraigned-again.html |title=Acquitted of Murder, but Arraigned Again |location=New York City; Georgia; Crown Heights (Nyc) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=August 5, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/24/nyregion/metro-digest-799095.html |title=METRO DIGEST – Summary |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=June 24, 1995 |accessdate=July 29, 2010}}</ref>
A warrant was issued for his arrest, which was deemed a parole violation.<ref name="nytimes3"/>
===Criminal trespass arrest (1996)=== Nelson was charged with criminal trespass on February 8, 1996. Police claimed that, having left a court hearing 90 minutes previously, Nelson was arrested after refusing to leave the lobby of an apartment building in which he did not live and that he was carrying a box cutter at the time.<ref name="findacase1"/><ref name="nydailynews1996">{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Greg B. |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1996/02/09/1996-02-09_crown_heights_suspect_in_new.html |title=Crown Heights Suspect In New Brush With Law |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=February 9, 1996 |accessdate=July 29, 2010 | location=New York}}</ref>
===Attack with icepick (2010)===
On September 12, 2010, Nelson was stabbed in the head with an [[icepick]] in a possible [[road rage]] incident.<ref name="nydailynews2"/> He was found outside his car at 168th Street and [[Riverside Drive (Manhattan)|Riverside Drive]] in upper Manhattan after 2:00 a.m., and brought to [[Harlem Hospital Center]] in stable condition.<ref name="nydailynews2"/><ref name="nytimes5"/><ref>[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/klyn_race_riot_killer_stabbed_in_Td2mEpADeAKWOqAJZjV4hP B'klyn race-riot killer stabbed in 'road rage']</ref>

They work to protect individuals and groups from [[political repression]] and [[discrimination]] by governments and private organizations, and seek to ensure the ability of all members of society to participate in the civil and political life of the [[State (polity)|state]].
Civil rights include [[individual rights]] to equal protection and service, [[privacy]], [[freedom of thought]], [[freedom of expression]], [[freedom of speech]], [[freedom of assembly]], [[freedom of movement|freedom to travel]], [[freedom of religion|freedom of worship]], protection of [[civil liberties]], the [[right to vote]], and the right to freely share ideas and opinions through all forms of communication and [[freedom of the press|media]].

[[File:MRM symbol.svg|thumb|A claimed Men's rights movement symbol.]] {{masculism sidebar}} '''Masculism''' or '''masculinism''' may variously refer to advocacy of the rights or needs of [[Man|men]] and [[boy]]s; and the adherence to or promotion of attributes (opinions, values, attitudes, habits) regarded as typical of men and boys.<ref name="BunninYu2008"/><ref name="Honderich1995">{{cite book|last=Christensen|first=Ferrell|editor=Ted Honderich|title=The Oxford Companion to Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ii8AAAAIAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-866132-0}}</ref><ref name=reason>{{cite news|publisher=''[[Reason magazine|Reason]]''|title=Man Troubles: Making Sense of the Men's Movement|author=[[Cathy Young]]|date=July 1994|url=http://reason.com/archives/1994/07/01/man-troubles|quote=Masculism (mas'kye liz*'em), n. 1. the belief that equality between the sexes requires the recognition and redress of prejudice and discrimination against men as well as women. 2. the movement organized around this belief. References Warren Farrell, Jack Kammer, and others activists in the men's movement.}}</ref>
==Definition and scope== The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (OED) defines ''masculism'', or synonymously ''masculinism'', as the "advocacy of the rights of men; adherence to or promotion of opinions, values, etc., regarded as typical of men; (more generally) anti-feminism, machismo."<ref>{{cite web|title=masculism, n|work=Oxford English Dictionary Online|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|edition=3rd |year=2000|accessdate=2015-02-17|quote=masculism, n. †1. The possession of masculine physical traits by a woman. Obs. rare. 2. = masculinism n.}}</ref><ref name="oedMasculinism">{{cite web|title=masculinism, n|work=Oxford English Dictionary Online|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=3rd |year=2000|accessdate=2015-02-17|quote=masculinism, n. Advocacy of the rights of men; adherence to or promotion of opinions, values, etc., regarded as typical of men; (more generally) anti-feminism, machismo.}}</ref>
However, philosopher Ferrell Christensen differentiates "masculism" from "masculinism", defining the latter as promoting the attributes of manliness.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> Political scientist Georgia Duerst-Lahti also distinguishes the two terms, with masculism expressing the ethos of the early gender-egalitarian [[men's movement]], while masculinism refers to the ideology of [[patriarchy]].<ref>{{citation | last = Duerst-Lahti | first = Georgia | contribution = Gender Ideology: masculinism and femininalism |pages=159–192 |editor1-last=Goertz |editor1-first=Gary |editor2-last=Mazur |editor2-first=Amy G. |title=Politics, gender, and concepts: theory and methodology |year=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9780521723428}}</ref><ref name="Dupuis-Déri2009">{{cite journal|last1=Dupuis-Déri|first1=Francis|title=Le " masculinisme ": une histoire politique du mot (en Anglais et en Français)| trans-title = “Masculinism”: a political history of the term (in English and French) |journal=Recherches Féministes |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=97–123 |url =https://doi.org/10.7202/039213ar |date=2009 |doi=10.7202/039213ar | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
Christensen differentiates between "progressive masculism" and an "extremist version". The former welcomes many of the societal changes promoted by feminists, while believing that some measures reducing sexism against women have increased it against men.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> Nicholas Davidson, in his book ''The Failure of Feminism'', describes an extremist version of masculism which he termed "virism": "What ails society is 'effeminacy'. The improvement of society requires that the influence of female values be decreased and the influence of male values increased…."<ref name="Honderich1995"/><ref name="Davidson1988">Christensen, Ferrell (2005), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WbkSDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA562 Masculism]", in {{cite book | editor-last = Honderich | editor-first = Ted | title = The Oxford companion to philosophy |pages=562–563 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | isbn = 9780199264797 }} * ''Citing'': {{cite book | last = Davidson | first = Nicholas | title = The failure of feminism |page=274 | publisher = Prometheus Books | location = Buffalo, New York | year = 1988 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=pf8pAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA274 | isbn = 9780879754082 }}</ref>
[[Gender theory|Gender theories]], which have frequently focused on woman-based or feminist approaches, have come to examine oppression in a masculist society also from the perspectives of men, many of whom are also subjected by that society.<ref name="HoogensenSolheim2006">Hoogensen, Gunhild; Solheim, Bruce Olav (2006), "[https://books.google.com/?id=ZPThCTMVsZQC&pg=PA21 Women in theory and practice]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Hoogensen | editor-first1 = Gunhild | editor-last2 = Solheim | editor-first2 = Bruce Olav |title=Women in power: world leaders since 1960|year=2006|page=21|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780275981907}}</ref> From a feminist perspective to philosophy, masculinism seeks to value and include only male views, and claim "that anything that cannot be reduced or translated in men's experience should be excluded from the subject-matter of philosophy.<ref name="BunninYu2008"/>
==Topic areas of interest== {{main|Men's rights movement}}
===Education and employment=== Many masculists oppose co-educational schooling, believing that single-sex schools better promote the well-being of boys.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"> {{cite journal | last1 = Blais | first1 = Melissa | last2 = Dupuis-Déri | first2 = Francis | title = Masculinism and the antifeminist countermovement | journal = [[Social Movement Studies|Social Movement Studies: Journal of Social, Cultural and Political Protest]] | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 21–39 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/14742837.2012.640532 | date = 2012 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14742837.2012.640532 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Other masculists and [[Equity feminism|equity feminists]] say that boys lag behind girls in educational achievement.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sommers |first1=Christina | author-link = Christina Hoff Sommers|title=The war against boys|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2000/05/the-war-against-boys/304659/|work= [[The Atlantic]] | date = May 2000 |accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
Data from the U.S. in 1994 reported that men suffer 94% of workplace fatalities. Masculist [[Warren Farrell]] has argued that men do a disproportionate share of dirty, physically demanding, and hazardous jobs.<ref name=reason/>
===Violence and suicide=== {{Violence against men}} {{See also|Violence against men}}
Masculists cite higher rates of suicide in men than women.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Masculists express concern about violence against men being depicted as humorous, in the media and elsewhere.<ref name=MYTH>{{cite book | last = Farrell | first = Warren | author-link = Warren Farrell | title = [[The Myth of Male Power|The myth of male power: why men are the disposable sex]] | publisher = [[Berkley Books]] | location = New York | year = 2001 | isbn = 9780425181447 }}</ref>
They also express concern about violence against men being ignored or minimized in comparison to violence against women,<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Mvulane | first = Zama | title = Do men suffer spousal abuse? | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090221033948/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20081125064002133C731559&set_id= | archive-date = February 21, 2009 | url = http://www.iol.co.za:80/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20081125064002133C731559&set_id= | work = [[Cape Times]] | via = [[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]] | location = South Africa | page = 12 | date = November 25, 2008 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> some asserting gender symmetry in [[domestic violence]].<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Another of their concerns is that traditional assumptions of female innocence or sympathy for women, termed [[benevolent sexism]], may lead to unequal penalties for women and men who commit similar crimes,<ref name="MYTH" /> to lack of sympathy for male victims in [[domestic violence]] cases, and to dismissal of female-on-male [[sexual assault]] and [[sexual harassment]] cases.
===Custody=== {{main|Fathers' rights movement}} According to [[David Benatar]], head of philosophy at the [[University of Cape Town]], "Custody law is perhaps the best-known area of men's rights activism", as it is more likely in most parts of the world for the mother to obtain custody of children in case of divorce. He argues: "When the man is the primary care-giver his chances of winning custody are lower than when the woman is the primary care-giver. Even when the case is not contested by the mother, he's still not as likely to get custody as when the woman's claim is uncontested".<ref>{{cite news | last = de Castella | first = Tom | title = Just who are men's rights activists? | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17907534 | work = [[BBC News Online#Features|BBC News Magazine]] | date = May 2, 2012 | access-date = May 3, 2012}}</ref>
== South African masculist evangelical movements == In the wake of the abolition of apartheid, South Africa has seen a resurgence of masculist Christian evangelical groups, led by two complementary men's and women's movements, the Mighty Men movement and the Worthy Women movement.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter">{{cite journal | last1 = Nadar | first1 = Sarojini | last2 = Potgieter | first2 = Cheryl | title = Liberated through submission?: The Worthy Woman's Conference as a case study of for''men''ism | journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion | volume = 26 | issue = 2 | pages = 141–151 | publisher = [[Project MUSE]] | date = Fall 2010 | url = https://muse.jhu.edu/article/394797 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> The Mighty Men movement harkens back to the Victorian idea of Muscular Christianity<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | last = Dube | first = Siphiwe | title = Muscular Christianity in contemporary South Africa: The case of the Mighty Men Conference | journal = HTS [[Theological Studies/Teologiese Studies]] | volume = 71 | issue = 3 | pages = 1–9 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = July 2015 | url = https://hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/2945/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> and the movement does not lead discussions about institutionalized racism.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last = Dube | first = Siphiwe | title = Race, whiteness and transformation in the Promise Keepers America and the Mighty Men Conference: A comparative analysis | journal = HTS [[Theological Studies/Teologiese Studies]] | volume = 72 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–8 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = November 2016 | url = http://www.hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/3476/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Feminist scholars argue that the movement's lack of attention to women's rights and their historical struggle with racial equality makes it a threat to women and to the stability of the country.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Scholar Miranda Pillay argues that the Mighty Men movement appeal lies in its resistance to gender equality as incompatible with Christian values, and in raising patriarchy to a "hyper-normative status," beyond challenge by other claims to power.<ref>Pillay, Miranda (2015), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yMTSCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 Mighty Men, Mighty Families: A pro-family Christian movement to (re)enforce patriarchal control?]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Conradie | editor-first1 = Ernst M. | editor-last2=Pillay| editor-first2=Miranda| title = Ecclesial reform and deform movements in the South African context | pages = 61–77 | publisher = African SUN MeDIA | location = Stellenbosch, South Africa | isbn = 9781920689766}}</ref>
The Worthy Women movement is a women's auxiliary to Mighty Men in advocating ''men''ism, a belief in the inherent superiority of men over women.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter" /> Their leader is Gretha Wiid. She blames South Africa's disorder on the liberation of women, and aims to restore the nation through its families, making women again subservient to their men.<ref>Nortjé-Meyer, Lilly (2015), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yMTSCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA86 A movement seeking to embody support of patriarchal structures and patterns in church and society: Gertha Wiid's Worthy Women movement]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Conradie | editor-first1 = Ernst M. | editor-last2=Pillay| editor-first2=Miranda| title = Ecclesial reform and deform movements in the South African context | pages = 86–93 | publisher = African SUN MeDIA | location = Stellenbosch, South Africa | isbn = 9781920689766}}</ref> Her success is attributed to her balancing claims that God created the gender hierarchy, but that women are no less valuable than men,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Nortjé-Meyer | first = Lilly | title = A critical analysis of Gretha Wiid’s sex ideology and her biblical hermeneutics | journal = Verbum et Ecclesia | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–7 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = November 2011 | url = http://verbumetecclesia.org.za/index.php/VE/article/view/472/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> and that restoration of traditional gender roles relieves existential anxiety in post-apartheid South Africa.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter"/>
==Reactions==
===Criticisms and responses=== Some critics believe masculism focuses on [[Chauvinism#Male chauvinism|male superiority]] or male dominance (i.e. [[androcentrism]])<ref>. ''Responses'': * {{cite web|title=masculinist, n|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/masculinist|website=merriam-webster.com|publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]]|accessdate=July 18, 2011}} * {{cite book | last = Brittan | first = Arthur | title = Masculinity and power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptFzQgAACAAJ&pg=PA4 | publisher = Basil Blackwell | location = Oxford New York | year = 1989 | isbn = 9780631141679 |page= 4|quote= ''Masculinism is the ideology that justifies and naturalizes male domination. As such it is the ideology of patriarchy. Masculinism takes it for granted that there is a fundamental difference between man and women, it assumes that heterosexuality is normal, it accepts without question the sexual division of labour, and it sanctions the political and dominant role of men in the public and private spheres.''}} * {{cite journal|last=Kahl|first=David H.|title=Analyzing Masculinist Movements: Responding to Antifeminism through Critical Communication Pedagogy|journal=Communication Teacher|volume=29|issue=1|year=2015|pages=21–26|doi=10.1080/17404622.2014.985600}} * Ruth, Sheila (1990), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HzYFAQAAIAAJ&pg=PT7 An introduction to women's studies]", in {{cite book | editor-last = Ruth | editor-first = Sheila | title = Issues in feminism: an introduction to women's studies | page = 7 | publisher = Mayfield | location = Mountain View, California | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9780874849370 | quote = ''Masculine-ism or masculism (sometimes called androcentrism) is the elevation of the masculine, conceptually and physically, to the level of the universal and ideal.'' }}</ref> to the exclusion of [[Woman|women]].<ref name="BunninYu2008">Bunnin, Nicholas; Yu, Jiyuan (2004), "[https://books.google.com/books?id=LdbxabeToQYC&pg=PA411 Masculinism]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Bunnin | editor-first1 = Nicholas | editor-last2 = Yu | editor-first2 = Jiyuan | title = The Blackwell dictionary of Western philosophy |page=411 | publisher = Blackwell | location = Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2004 | isbn = 9780470997215 }}</ref> Some masculinists believe that differentiated gender roles are natural. {{non-sequitur|date=July 2018}} There is some evidence for social influences (e.g. gender division of labor, socialization) as the sole or primary origin of gender differentiation.<ref name="Risman, Barbara 2004">{{cite journal | last = Risman | first = Barbara J. | author-link = Barbara Risman | title = Gender as a social structure: theory wrestling with activism | journal = [[Gender & Society]] | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 429–450 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0891243204265349 | jstor = 4149444 | date = August 2004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/0891243204265349 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Basow | first = Susan A. | title = Gender: stereotypes and roles | publisher = Brooks/Cole | location = Pacific Grove, California | year = 1992 | edition = 3rd | isbn = 9780534121204 }}</ref> Some parts of the masculinist movement have to some extent borrowed concepts from [[evolutionary psychology]]: this theory argues that adaptation during prehistory resulted in complementary but different roles for the different genders, and that this balance has been destabilized by feminism since the 1960s.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/>
===Feminism=== Some masculinists have been described as explicitly antifeminist by feminist activists.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> According to Blais and Dupuis-Déri, "the contents of [masculinist] websites and the testimony of feminists that we questioned confirm that masculinists are generally critical of even moderate feminists and feminists at the head of official feminist organizations."<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Some masculinist activism has involved disruption of events organized by feminists and lawsuits against feminist academics, journalists, or activists.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Furthermore, masculinist actions are sometimes extreme; father's rights activists have bombed family courts in Australia and have issued bomb threats in the UK, although it is ambiguous whether there was public and organized militant group involvement.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> They have also engaged in "tire-slashing, the mailing of excrement-filled packages, threats against politicians and their children."<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Spokesmen for these groups have also spoken out against public awareness campaigns to prevent sexual assault, arguing that they portray a negative image of men, and one masculinist group harassed administrators of dozens of battered women's shelters and women's centers.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/><ref>{{cite book | last1 = Martin | first1 = Janet M. | last2 = Borrelli | first2 = Maryanne | title = The other elites: Women, politics, and power in the Executive Branch | publisher = Lynne Rienner Publishers | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 2001 | isbn = 9781555879716 }}</ref>
Philosopher Ferrell Christensen states that if masculism and feminism refer to the belief that men/women are systematically discriminated against, and that this discrimination should be eliminated, there is not necessarily a conflict between feminism and masculism, and some assert that they are both.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> However, many believe that one sex is more discriminated against, and thus use one label and reject the other.<ref name="Honderich1995"/>
